titleStmt.title: Vincit qui patitur or Lieutenant Colonel John Lylborne decyphered, in a short answer of Captaine Wendy Oxford to a most notoriously false pamphlet of the said Lylborns intituled Iohn Lylborne revived printed at Bruges in Flanders. With a short letter, which was sent to him in Iuly last to give his satisfaction then, why I printed not what I had then finished for the press, in answer to his scandalous pamphlet printed at Viana in May last. With some allegations against the said Mr. Lylborne which the world knowes to be truth, of his writings, actions, plottings, and contryvings, against the late murthered king, his royall queene, posteritie, nobility spiritual and temporal, ...
titleStmt.author: Oxford, Wendy.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 22 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

notesStmt.note: Transcribed from: (Early English Books Online ; image set 157737)

titleStmt.title: Vincit qui patitur or Lieutenant Colonel John Lylborne decyphered, in a short answer of Captaine Wendy Oxford to a most notoriously false pamphlet of the said Lylborns intituled Iohn Lylborne revived printed at Bruges in Flanders. With a short letter, which was sent to him in Iuly last to give his satisfaction then, why I printed not what I had then finished for the press, in answer to his scandalous pamphlet printed at Viana in May last. With some allegations against the said Mr. Lylborne which the world knowes to be truth, of his writings, actions, plottings, and contryvings, against the late murthered king, his royall queene, posteritie, nobility spiritual and temporal, ...
titleStmt.author: Oxford, Wendy.

publicationStmt.date: Printed the first of Aprill in the yeare of God 1653.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2010-08 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2011-06 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: Vincit qui patitur OR LIUTENANT COLONEL JOHN LYLBORNE Decyphered, in a short an≈øwer of Captaine WENDY OXFORD To a mo≈øt notoriou≈øly fal≈øe pamphlet of the ≈øaid Lylborns intituled Iohn Lylborne Revived printed at Bruges in Flanders.

With a short letter, which was ≈øent to him in Iuly la≈øt to give him ≈øatisfaction then, why I printed not what I had then finished for the Pre≈øs, in an≈øwer to his ≈øcandalous pamphlet printed at Viana in May la≈øt.

q.p: Then ≈øayd the Prophet Jeremiah unto the Prophet Hananiah, Heare now Hananiah, the Lord had not ≈øent thee, but thou make≈øt this people to tru≈øt in a lie.
Therefore thus ≈øayeth the Lord, Beholde, I will ca≈øt thee from off the earth: this yeere thou ≈øhalt die, becau≈øe thou ha≈øt ≈øpoken rebelliou≈øly again≈øt the Lord.

div.p: With ≈øome allegations again≈øt the ≈øaid Mr. Lylborne which the world knowes to be truth, of his writings, actions, plottings, and contryvings, again≈øt the late murthered King, his Royal Queene, Po≈øteritie, Nobilitity Spiritual and Temporal, and all others of the learned Orthodox Divines, quite contrary to the advice of Solomon Prov. the 29. ver≈ø. 18. Amos the 8. P≈øalme 19. Saint Mathew the 11. the 10. Corinthians the fir≈øt, the 6. and the 6. Galath. the 6 and the 6. Acts the 10. Heb. 13. and 17. ver≈ø. and in a word contrary to the whole rules of Scripture, ≈øo that feaw or none (≈øaying of His owne wicked and perver≈øe party) will beleeue his reports.
Printed the fir≈øt of Aprill in the yeare of God 1653.

div.head: The Pre≈øent an≈øwer of Cap: WENDY OXFORD To a ≈øcandalous Paper of Mr. JOHN LYLBORNE
div.p:
I Need not to in≈øi≈øt much upon my di≈øcour≈øe, all people ≈øo well knowing the nature of the object, to an≈øwer whom is now my taske in this onely ≈øheet of paper: more monyes I have not to ≈øpend ≈øo much in vaine (notwith≈øtanding Mr. Lilbornes great reports of Salleryes receiving from England) which is well knowne to the contrary, neither have I ≈øuch collections, beggings, and continual recruits which Mr. Lilborne weekly recives from his Brother hood and faction in England, by rea≈ø≈øon I give not ≈øuch advi≈øe in my letters to tho≈øe of England as he doth weekly, which He takes the impudency to Iu≈øtifie the ≈øame in part of his pamphlets, by a litle you may judge of the re≈øt, He is ≈øo much an Engli≈øhman as ever He was, not to have King nor States to doe harme to his Brother rebells and traytors in England, to that end he writs to ≈øome in England his oppinions concerning ≈øea and Land ≈øervice which may fall out cro≈øs to the de≈øignes of the rebells enemies of England. The Proverb often times prooves truth, That a Standerby ≈øees better then he that plaies, to that end he remaines among≈øt the Parliaments friends to give aime again≈øt both our King, and the States of the≈øe united Provinces, being between both. But had I ≈øuch ≈øumes of moneys as he reports, he ≈øhould have heard undoubtedly from me ere this; having had 24. ≈øheets of Paper ready for the pre≈øs the≈øe 9. monthes in two volumes, the one Intituled.
The Banished-mans Complaint, the other Iohn Lylbornes Portaicture with A Hue and Cry after Him.
Nay had I ≈øuch ≈øumes as he reports, I would not have ≈øuffered my booke intituled.

The Pro≈øpective Gla≈øs for King and ≈øubjects to have layn Printed 9. monthes in the Printers hands and not ≈øent them into the World imediatly after their birth, where in Mr. Lylborne is more at larg di≈øcovered, his cruelty and barbari≈øme laid open to all readers.

But why doe I hold thee in the porch (Courteious reader) when the hou≈øe is ≈øo litle. Therefore welcom to the re≈øt, and in briefe, who ≈øo hath, or ≈øhall plea≈øe to read the 8 page of Mr Lilbornes letter directed to Mr D.D. in the united Provinces, may find the tearme he gives me. of Spy of Cromwells and Scotts, and ≈øayeth my booke intituled The unexpected Life, (given by Lilborne and his faction) and the long wished for death of the thing called Parliament in England, is fal≈øe and on purpo≈øs, to have his throate cutt, ≈øo that no man mu≈øt write or ≈øpeake what he hath done for that cau≈øe. But let me tell Mr Lilborne, that what I write in that booke again≈øt him, and ten times more then I ≈øhall here in≈øert, that tho≈øe he termes Cavaliers here, and els where, knowes to be too great a truth, therefore the more he goes about to vaile his former, and ≈øtill vilany, He will but give him ≈øelfe the lye. For hath not many
told him to his face the ≈øame; and doth not all know that John Lylborne (when he was but an aprenti≈øe boy in London) was one of the very fir≈øt (if not the fir≈øt) that ever endeavored to make a ≈øeparation between the late murthered King and his People: The Dutch al≈øo can not be ignorant thereof, for, for that very cau≈øe did he fly in to the≈øe Lands, and his re≈øidence was here in Delph, and my printer was his in tho≈øe dayes, & he made a Burgur here of Delph at the ≈øame time. O yes you (Mr Lylborne) are very well known to be the in≈øurecter in chiefe, and him who brought great tumults to white Hall that had not Capt: Endimion Porter immediatly with his trayn band, the Nobility and Stout-hearted gentery in Court a≈ø≈øi≈øted each other, the ≈øence murthered King, his Queene and Royal progenie had undoubtedly been then murthered, ≈øo that you had ≈øaved the murtherurs at We≈øtmin≈øter a great deale of Honor, and co≈øtly trouble to the 3 Kingdomes: It is likewi≈øe known to all at home and a broad of your owne nation, that after that in≈øurrection again≈øt the King &c. in the rebellious city of London and Southwarke you did ray≈øe the ≈øame rable, and (had not the traine bands likewi≈øe prevented) violently fell on Lambeth Hou≈øe and have kild his Grace of Canterbury, though ≈øence butchered by your bretheren. And doth not the three nations ring of you (Mr Lylborne) for cau≈ø≈øing libells to be throun in his Maje≈øtyes coach, as he pa≈øt the ≈øtreets of London, and doe not all know you were one of the fir≈øt Actors in the late bloody warre, and death of the late murthered King, ever po≈øting betwixt the Divells in the Army, and the Turks in London, but of this more at large els where; And for the pre≈ø≈øent I reffer the reader to your owne workes (Iack) of 44. bookes by you printed, or at lea≈øt owned (in your Appologie) and ≈øence: in all of which, if there be not Trea≈øon, Con≈øpiricie Fal≈øe Doctrine and Heri≈øy, this is not truth, e≈øpecialy by rea≈øon my memory is fre≈øh with your pampehlet from Viana in May la≈øt, wherein if any plea≈øe to view the 12 pag they may find your a≈øpertions on the pre≈øent King, and your fixe Re≈øolutions again≈øt the Scotts King (as you term him) to be irrevocable; and you (Iacke) take pre≈øumtion upon you there to ≈øet downe the rea≈øons, and in the ≈øame page ≈øay that you will not lo≈øe your party, to ≈øet his Intere≈øt on foote; in a word all your pamphlets are compo≈ø≈øed of nought elce but ≈øeditious names, of Tyrannie and oppre≈ø≈øion in monarchy, and you cloake all your rebellion under hone≈øt magna Charta, which had tho≈øe valiant old Britanes thought it ≈øhould have beene ≈øo much abu≈øed by ≈øuch evile Spirits as thou art, they would have made a bone-fire of it, although it co≈øt ≈øo deare as it did. Now let me further tell thee (reader) veiw but that pamphlet, and this la≈øt of his at Bruges, and you ≈øhall ≈øee, that he labours covertly to di≈øtroy this Kings intere≈øt in all States, under covert of the fredome of the people of England, crying it up, which the world knows cannot be with out their King, as well as a King con≈øi≈øts in the ≈øafety of his people, but not a word of a crowne, or King, (except in detraction and deri≈ø≈øion thereof) in all his workes, O that is contrary to the motions of his Spirit: which now he would fayn vaile over to cheat true hearts out of their under≈øtandings, and if you plea≈øe impartialy to view Mr Lylborns de≈øignes in the la≈øt page of his letter to Mr. D D, wherein he confe≈ø≈øeth, the Dutch may be angry with him &c: (a guilty con≈øcience needs no accu≈ø≈øer) but ≈øayeth Mr. Lylborne there he is no hearty enemy of the Dutch, but a true borne Engli≈øh-man, and truly if all Engli≈øhmen
really ob≈øerve that onely page of his, they would have ≈ømal cau≈øe to thinke well on Jacke Lylborne, for, he ≈øhews what he would be at, neither for Dutch, King, nor any elce but him≈øelfe and his crue, for ≈øaith he therein, that he de≈øiers with all his heart, an hone≈øt peace may be concluded, and ≈øoundly ≈øetled between the two States, to the rational ≈øecuring di≈øtinctly, the rights and Priveledges of each nation with out encroachments of either ≈øide by ≈øtripping the great ‚Äî on both ≈øides (here in is old Jacke Lylborne revived in ill Language) and Levelling one with an other, (that being his profe≈ø≈øed game) from their arbitrary and Tyranical power ≈øayth he, (thers an other chipp of the old blocke) and ≈øo goes on prote≈øting that if his ≈øchattered power and interre≈øt, could contribute any thing to the accompli≈øhing of ≈øuch a peace and a greement, he would heartily venture his Life &c: with more large expre≈ø≈øions. Now you may immagine the rea≈ø≈øon hereof, and the good which will ari≈øe thereon That if a peace &c. the King may ≈øeeke his fortune, and con≈øequently all loyal and true hearted Engli≈øhmen of great e≈øtates, high birth (and too good breeding) to be kept from their old and rightfull po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions: but in deed (Jacke) neither Engli≈øh or Dutch mu≈øt ever looke to ≈øee peace and quietne≈øs in the 3 Kingdomes of England &c. nor in deed the≈øe Netherlands 2 yeares togeather with out the Crowne be ≈øetled on the rightfull Heire, for it will be a pre≈ø≈øident and high way to di≈øtruction, of all Monarchy in the world, and ≈øet up oppre≈ø≈øive Anarchy in ≈øteed thereof which the Lord of Ho≈øtes but no doubt will, open the eyes of all Princes (in Chri≈øtendome e≈øpecially) for the prevention thereof, and breake the cords of all ≈øuch unlawful pre≈øidents: be≈øides it will be ≈øuch a moate, in the eyes of the Netherlands, that it will not be ≈øoon picked out) for all he clawes the Dutch in the ≈øaid Letter, who≈øe wi≈ødome is too great for his delu≈øive wayes. View what he writes to his Intelligencer Mr. D D. (whom I doe avow if ≈øo, to be the Sonn of perdition and not of an hone≈øt woman) for, the time is yet to come, that ever I thought, or ≈øpake of the Death of John Lylborne, I have other thinges to talke of on, then ≈øuch a perver≈øe di≈øpo≈øition; but as I ≈øayd marke well how he would claw &c: for ≈øaith he in the la≈øt lines of that letter, what he would doe, if the Dutch would but give Oliver a box on the eare, he would give one on the other in his way, if not, account him a knave‚ñ™ (many thinkes that noe newes, any time his 18 or 20 yeares) but ob≈øerve the box on the eare, would be both to the Engli≈øh and Dutch, for ≈øhould they agree, they ‚Ä¢ u≈øt looke to be in warre with all neighbouring nations, taking part with ≈øuch a people who≈øe thir≈øt for blood, is not to be quenched, untill they be ≈øerved as.Alexander was, or the 30 Tyrants of Athens, for that the Trea≈øury of the≈øe lands will not onely be exhau≈øted, but for ever remaine empty enough: Now where as Mr. John fal≈øely calumniateth me againe in the 4 and 5 pag of his booke, by the name Spy of the Engli≈øh and Dutch, and that He routed me from Am≈øterdam, many at the Hague, Am≈øterdam and elce where knowes to the contrary, for the Landlord, Landlady, and other lodgers in the Hou≈øe wherein our aboad was there, and Capt‚ñ™ Rawlins told Lylborne that to be a cruel Lye to his face (as I am Informed by ≈øome of them ≈øelves) for I long before re≈øolved to depart that Citty, as, „Äà‚óä„Äâ being too deare a place, and not ≈ø ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¶ lthfull as where I am, which Citty I de≈øigned for my a boade, at my ve ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ fir≈øt landing: and where as ‚Ä¢ e wickedly and in deed diabolically ‚Ä¶ er≈øes mee wi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the contriving
his murther at Bruges and Am≈øterdam, I have more largely cleared that poynt elce where, only give me leave, to let you know his bloody con≈øcience is ≈øo guilty, that he feares more then ordinary, for if I had, had ≈øuch an intent, and was to have, or had a ≈øallery, for the contriving his murther, I could have di≈øpatcht him long ≈øence, as wee traveld togeather in ≈øhipps, in our Iourney from England, or as wee lay togeather often times in Am≈øterdam, in his or my owne chamber: and as for hiering at the fir≈øt coming over, or ≈øence, any of the Duke of Lorraignes men, or any elce, I neither could then, or can I well yet, either ≈øpeake, or under≈øtand the languages of forreigne nations, or had I, or have I yet any ≈øuch acquaintance in the Lorraignes army, or any ≈øuch murthering, bloodthir≈øty, and bloodminded people, as any tho≈øe he pretends, and as him ≈øelfe hath, and ≈øtill is to be feared yet remaines, otherwi≈øe he could never ≈øymphatyze ≈øo much with the di≈øpo≈øi≈øtion of the Devill, the father of all mi≈øchiefe, wherefore at pre≈øent I ≈øhall onely make this prote≈øtation, again≈øt all his particulars and Generalls; That I de≈øier all my other ≈øinnes may be forgiven me at the la≈øt day, ≈øaving tho≈øes he charges me with, of murther in a mo≈øt ample way, of him in particular, and many in the general of both Nations, as al≈øo that dete≈øtable on of La≈øciviou≈øne≈ø≈øe, (no Jacke) I am none of your adimantical romancers neither am I one of your faction, that hold it noe ≈øinne to doe with a ≈øi≈øter when the Spirit moves, neither am I ≈øo cowerdly as you terme it, to plott, or contrive any mans murther, in a ba≈øe ignoble way, e≈øpecialy yours, at that time, when I had not occa≈øsion for it, you never de≈øerving from me any unkindne≈øs (as to my owne ≈øelfe) untill your pamphlet from Viana came forth, yet I ≈øcorne to thinke of ≈øuch heatheni≈øs practices, or Italian lacivious engagements. Wherefore John Lylborne on what grounds the≈øe jealou≈øes ari≈øeth I can not conciev of your thus raving, and when you write againe, I pray in your next ≈øcurilous paper name them outright in your ≈øuper≈øcriptious, and al≈øo in your inward parts of your pamphlets nominate your intelligencers, whoe are not only the blow coales between you and mee but elce where, then I doubt not but it will appeare to the world, thou ha≈øt been as erroneou≈øly perver≈øe to mee, as thou ha≈øt been generaly again≈øt all goodne≈øs, hone≈øty and ≈øound judgement from thy child-hood; nay again≈øt all people (≈øaving of thy owne faction,) againe where as Mr. Lylborne in the 4 and 5th. pages charges me with the name Spy on Dutch and Engli≈øh I leave all to my former bookes of ≈øatisfaction, E≈øpicialie my booke cal'd
The Hue and Cry, after Iohn Lylborne, Or, O Iacke art thou found.

Onely de≈øiering all Dutch and Engli≈øh, Iri≈øh and Scotts, to thinke of me as they have hither unto found both my behaviour and inqui≈øitions in Company keepings, and ≈øhall begg of them which knowes me not (but by the pen of ≈øuch a one, whoe never ≈øence he could fir≈øt hold it would write any thing elce, but that which portented to ≈øedition and con≈øpiracie, again≈øt publick or private per≈øons) wherefore I de≈øier all to ca≈øt their ≈øerious eyes, and make deepe inqui≈ø≈øitions both of my ge≈øtures, actions, and di≈øpo≈ø≈øitions pa≈øt and to come, and then to a proove ad probatum. Which I doubt not (if I ≈øhould be que≈øtioned in the≈øe lands, by the fal≈øe ≈øugge≈øtions of Lylborne, that there are many per≈øons of Honor of the Nations of Dutch, Engli≈øh,
Scotts, Iri≈øh, and French, whoe would give a character of mee as they haue found, having made deepe ≈øearches into my waies, for their owne ≈øatisfactions, which I forbeare at present, or in future to mention, as not being bound there unto by an≈øwer to any Scandalous pen (much le≈øs to thine Jacke, whoe is ≈øo well knowne cannot touch paper but in letters of blood and maintenance of rebellion, malice, and extreordinary ≈øelfe conceit; thinking thereby, either to force, or feare tho≈øe thou writs again≈øt to be of thy in ≈øolidity and factiou≈øly wicked, and perver≈øly unparraleld nature.) and where as thou give≈øt the terme of whore to one (whoe were ≈øhe not of ≈øo neare a relation unto me as ≈øhee is) I ≈øhould then ≈øay more then I ≈øhall at pre≈øent for that the whole world knowes thee to have written again≈øt tho≈øe and cal'd them ≈øoe in thy pamphletts, who≈øe feet ≈øhee is not worthy to wipe, but ≈øhe is ≈øo well known in the≈øe parts, of her life and conver≈øation, of her di≈øcent and breeding, that thy pen can not injure her, and for her journeys making into England it is ≈øo wel known here to the better ≈øort, that ≈øhee goes not about any ≈øuch matter aledged again≈øt her, or me in that nature, wherefore when thou write≈øt unto me or any body elce, ≈øhew not the eye of mi≈øunder≈øtanding, and ≈øacrifice not they great man hood ≈øo much by thee blazed Iacke, in this pamphlet again≈øt an innocent creature and on of the weaker ve≈ø≈øells. A las Jacke, I throught thou had≈øt not forgotten the rule of ≈øchooleboys ≈øoe much: but what ≈øhall I ≈øay more to all gentlemen, then what I have alredy at pre≈øent, and to the Jacke Lylborne, more then the copy of the letter under written, which I de≈øire all to read, and judge accordingly. But Jacke, to witnes they fal≈øitie to the King, let all Gentlemen in quier if thou ha≈øt not bought his Pallace of Thibalds which co≈øt the but ≈øix thou≈ø≈øand pounds, of which thou ha≈øt alredy made before thy comming over, ≈øeaven thou≈ø≈øand five hundred pounds of onely the wan≈øcote, chimney peeces, lead, Gla≈øs and Irone, and converted the re≈øt into above a hundred Tenniments.

div.head: A Copy of a Letter ≈øent to Mr. Lylborne &c.
div.p:
By your uncivil pen and haire braned folly you haue cau≈øed mee (as much as in you lyes) to ≈øtand charged and guilty of many ungentleman like actions, the burthen whereof (was not your pear≈ø≈øon and faction: ≈øo well knowen that they Honor more then dishonour by rayling &c. again≈øt tho≈øe you write) would be too heavy long to beare, but having the patrocing of Iohn Lylborne, it is not felt at all, which were an other the authour, I might then expre≈øs a no le≈øs ea≈ø≈øy, then I doe now a ≈øafe i≈ø≈øue and good ≈øucce≈øs in the vindication of my owne innocency, which I de≈øier tho≈øes that know us both, and ≈øuch us know neither of us, but by our lines, that neither my rashne≈øs may plead my innocencie, nor your bra≈ø≈øene≈øs my guilt, but
that all true hearted gentlemen would conceive of my defences as they are of them ≈øelves with out reference to either (as I shall endeavore ≈øo to pre≈øent them,) and I doubt not but when ever I shal re≈øolve to goe out of the≈øe countres, I shall goe as cleerly ju≈øtified, as I am at pre≈øent in the te≈øtimony of a good con≈øcience concerning your allegations: and I doubt not with the ble≈ø≈øing of God, but to pul out tho≈øe poy≈ønous arrowes of ba≈øe and unworthy actions which you indeavour to feather in the hearts of Gentlemen of all nations purpo≈øsly to make me odious in the no≈øtrils of tho≈øe heroicke Spirits who hitherto abhorre to heare your name or bookes ≈øpoken of. Sr you would make hogsheads and whole tunes of ≈øome one or two cupps of wine, to the end, that ≈øome petty mi≈øs alledged errors of mine may be ≈øo intoxicated, that they are put in the elevation of the highe≈øt and damnable crimes of mankind: but really it hath not been in my genius to di≈øcerne ≈øuch mon≈øters in my brea≈øt, as you by your ≈øini≈øterous informations endeavor to ≈øtick to heart: but had I the lea≈øt ≈øu≈øpition in my ≈øelfe of any thing you charge me withall, I would ≈øpare you further writing, confe≈øs all, and through the fir≈øt ≈øtone at my ≈øelfe, nay pa≈øs ≈øentence of condemnation al≈øo. Which if you write more, I shall an≈øwer more at large. Then have at you in the name of the Lord, ≈øit as fa≈øt as you can, I will di≈ømount you from your ≈øaddles of refuges of Viana &c. out of the≈øe Lands: and when I have hunted you out hence, I shall ≈øend further hue and cryes into tho≈øe Lands where ever you are re≈øiding. So re≈øolves

closer.signed: Your forgiving Enemy upon repentance to God, and Wendy Oxford

div.p: This letter made him for≈øake Viana as you ≈øee and goe to Brugges, to the countreys of his bretherens friend the Spaniard, which no Prince in Chri≈øtendome but refu≈øeth to corre≈øpond with them and Lylborne, nay the heatheni≈øh Princes, onely the Span≈øh, but it may come in time to his owne pallaces the ≈øame which hath happened by rebellion in my Land, if ≈øoe noe pitty by my con≈øent on him nor his.
